## Enough!

Stop working out of your Download Folders!

+ File organization is a big component of GIS work (or any other computer based analysis)
+ Take the time to set up a project folder and organize your data.
+ _Sooooo_ many of the problems you are having are related to poor file organization!
+ You should never feel sad about deleting the entire contents of your download folder!

## Enough!

Also, when you get a zip..

+ Extract the files to your project directory (and organize if need by)
+ Leave the zip in your downloads and never glance at it again.

## File Organization and Computer Hygiene
:::{style="margin-right: 520px; font-size: 0.5em"}
Be kind to your future self - keep your files organized:

+ Use directories (a.k.a folders)
+ Use descriptive names:
  + e.g. `slo_county_26910.geojson` not `county.geojson`
+ Don't put spaces in file or directory names (see [this](https://authors.library.caltech.edu/records/mmnpf-cez11))
:::

![](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/documents.png){.absolute top=100 right=0 height=500}

## How to Organize your files {style="font-size:0.5em"}
+ Pick a convention and be consistent
+ For example:

```
/Work/NR_classes/
├── Class1/
│   └── ...
├── NR218/
│   ├── Project_1/
│   │   └── ...
│   └── Project_2/
│       ├── Vector/
│       │   ├── trees.parquet
│       │   └── streams.geogjson
|       ├── Raster/
│       │   ├── dem.tif
│       │   └── rainfall.h5
│       ├── qgis/
│       │   └── project_2.qmd
│       └── Results/
│           ├── Figures/
│           │   ├── figure1.png
│           │   ├── figure2.png
│           │   └── map.png
│           └── proj_2_report.doc
```

## Final Project Tips {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Scope realistically: pick a focused area and question.
- Secure data early; verify availability before committing to a topic.
- Document intermediate products (screenshots, stats) as you go.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-013.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Final Project Tips: Time Dimension {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Choose comparison windows that match your phenomenon (e.g., pre/post fire, seasonal contrasts).
- Temporal analyses reveal dynamics in hydrology, vegetation, ocean conditions, and more.

## Debugging GIS Workflows {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Translate cryptic error messages into keywords for Google, StackExchange, or ChatGPT.
- Describe what you were doing when the problem appeared; context helps others help you.
- Step away briefly—fresh eyes solve many stubborn issues.
- Collaborate; many GIS puzzles are easier as a team.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-017.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Think Like a Computer {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Follow instructions exactly: correct order, layers, and parameters.
- When tools misbehave:
  - Remove and re-add the layer.
  - Restart QGIS and retry the workflow.
- Remember: computers execute exactly what we specify—precision matters.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-018.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

- Success requires patience, discipline, resilience, and curiosity.
- Frustration is normal; letting it derail progress isn’t.

## New Material: Geocoding {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Geocoding converts addresses to coordinates; reverse geocoding does the opposite.
- Supports planning, demographics, and many location-based analyses.
- Numerous free tools and APIs exist—use them responsibly.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-020.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Tutorial: Export QGIS Data to Excel {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Open the Swanton dataset in QGIS.
- Right-click `sprLandUse` → `Export` → `MS Office Open XML spreadsheet (XLSX)`.
- Save the file to an accessible location (e.g., Desktop or OneDrive).

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-021.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Online: Load GIS Data {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Visit [office.com](https://office.com) and sign in with CP credentials.
- Explore apps → open Excel → `File` → `Open` → `Open files from this device`.
- Select the exported XLSX to view GIS attributes in Excel Online.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-022.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Basics: Sort & Filter {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Use the funnel icon to enable filters on each column header.
- Sort ascending/descending and filter categories to explore the dataset.
- Observe how filtering impacts downstream calculations.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-023.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Analysis: Summaries & Charts {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Build mini-tables to compute metrics (e.g., % land area by use).
- Highlight data → `Insert` → `Chart` to visualize (pie, column, etc.).
- Format data labels and legends for clarity.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-024.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Analysis: Pivot Tables {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Select a categorical field (e.g., `LUType`) and a numeric field (`Acres`).
- `Data` tab → `Analyze Data` → `Insert Pivot Table`.
- Inspect the generated sheet to see totals by category; experiment with other stats.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-025.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Analysis: Histograms {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Highlight the `Acres` column → `Insert` → `Chart` → `Histogram`.
- Adjust bin width to reveal distribution patterns and outliers.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-026.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Excel Analysis: Scatterplots & Trendlines {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Select paired fields (e.g., `height` vs `diameter`) → `Insert` → `Scatter`.
- Add trendlines and display equation plus R² to assess relationships.
- When values cluster along an axis, use logarithmic scales to spread the data.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-028.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## New Material: ArcGIS Pro Overview {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- ESRI’s enterprise GIS platform; widely used in government and large nonprofits.
- Feature-rich and user-friendly but proprietary, Windows-only, and licensed.
- Fewer plugins/community resources compared to QGIS; plan support accordingly.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-034.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## Tutorial: ArcGIS Pro Setup {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Launch ArcGIS Pro from the Start menu.
- Download `SwantonGIS.gdb.zip` from Canvas and extract it.
- In ArcGIS Pro: `Map` → `Add Data` → browse to the unzipped GDB.
- Drag layers from the geodatabase into the map.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-035.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## ArcGIS Pro: Symbology {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- Category symbology: right-click layer (e.g., `sprVegetation`) → `Symbology` → `Unique Values` → choose field (`Vegtype1`).
- Graduated styling: experiment with numerical fields (`sprSoils`):
  - `Graduated Colors` with `KFACTOR`.
  - `Graduated Symbols` with `Depth`.
  - `Proportional Symbols` with `SlopeMax`.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-037.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}

## ArcGIS Pro: Layouts & Export {style="font-size:0.7em"}

- `Insert` → `New Layout` → `8.5 x 11 Letter`; set scale (e.g., 1:55,000).
- Add map frame, north arrow, scale bar, legend, and grid coordinates.
- Share the finished map via `Share` → `Export Map`, setting filename and path.

![](assets/intro_excel_arc-038.jpg){style="max-height: 420px; margin: 1.5rem auto; display: block;"}
